title: MATH401 Midterm Examination
instructions: This exam covers Topics 1-4: Complex Numbers, Analytic Functions, Complex Integration, and Cauchy's Theorem.
Show all work for full credit.
You may use one formula sheet.

questions.prompt: Compute (3 + 4i)(2 - i) and express in standard form.
Find all cube roots of 8i.
questions.explanation: 8i = 8e^(iπ/2). Cube roots: 2e^(i(π/2 + 2πk)/3) for k=0,1,2, giving 2e^(iπ/6), 2e^(i5π/6), 2e^(i3π/2)

questions.prompt: Which set is NOT open in ℂ?
questions.explanation: The set {z : |z - i| ≤ 2} includes its boundary (≤ not <), so it is closed, not open.

questions.prompt: For f(z) = z³, what is ∂u/∂x where u = Re(f)?
questions.explanation: z³ = (x+iy)³ = x³ - 3xy² + i(3x²y - y³). So u = x³ - 3xy², and ∂u/∂x = 3x² - 3y²

questions.prompt: Is the function f(z) = |z|² analytic anywhere?
questions.explanation: f(z) = x² + y², so u = x² + y², v = 0. C-R equations are satisfied only at (0,0)

questions.prompt: What is the derivative of f(z) = e^(z²)?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: f'(z) = e^(z²) · d/dz(z²) = 2ze^(z²)

questions.prompt: What is the modulus of z = -3 + 4i?
Every analytic function is infinitely differentiable.
questions.explanation: This is a fundamental property of analytic functions, following from Cauchy's integral formula.

questions.prompt: The principal argument of z = -1 - i is:
questions.explanation: z = -1 - i is in the third quadrant. arg(z) = arctan(-1/-1) + π adjusted = -3π/4 (principal value in (-π, π])

questions.prompt: Which of the following is NOT a Cauchy-Riemann equation?
questions.explanation: The Cauchy-Riemann equations are: ∂u/∂x = ∂v/∂y and ∂u/∂y = -∂v/∂x. The third option reverses the sign incorrectly.

questions.prompt: Use Cauchy's integral formula to evaluate ∫_{|z|=1} e^z/z dz.
questions.explanation: By Cauchy's formula with f(z) = e^z, a = 0: ∫ = 2πi·f(0) = 2πi·1 = 2πi

questions.prompt: Which statement about Liouville's theorem is correct?
options: Every bounded entire function is constant
Every entire function has a zero
questions.explanation: Liouville's theorem: If f is entire and bounded, then f is constant.

questions.prompt: Apply the maximum modulus principle: if f is analytic on |z| ≤ 1 and |f(z)| ≤ 3 for |z| = 1, what is max|f(z)| for |z| ≤ 1?
questions.explanation: Maximum modulus principle: maximum of |f| on a closed bounded domain is attained on the boundary.

questions.prompt: The function f(z) = z̄ (complex conjugate) is analytic everywhere.
questions.explanation: f(z) = z̄ does not satisfy the Cauchy-Riemann equations anywhere, so it is nowhere analytic.

questions.prompt: What is e^(iπ) equal to?
questions.explanation: By Euler's formula: e^(iπ) = cos(π) + i·sin(π) = -1 + 0 = -1

questions.prompt: Evaluate ∫_{|z|=2} dz/(z²+1).
questions.explanation: Poles at z = ±i. Residues sum to 0: Res(f,i) = 1/(2i), Res(f,-i) = -1/(2i). Total = 0.

questions.prompt: State the Cauchy-Goursat theorem.
options: If f is analytic on and inside γ, then ∫_γ f = 0
If f is continuous on γ, then ∫_γ f = 0
If f has a pole inside γ, then ∫_γ f = 2πi
The integral depends only on endpoints
questions.explanation: Cauchy-Goursat: If f is analytic on a simply connected domain containing γ, then ∫_γ f(z)dz = 0

questions.prompt: Find the radius of convergence of Σ(n!z^n).
questions.explanation: Using ratio test: |aₙ₊₁/aₙ| = (n+1)|z| → ∞ for any z ≠ 0. So R = 0.

questions.prompt: Find the radius of convergence of Σ(z^n/n!).
questions.explanation: This is the series for e^z. The ratio test gives R = ∞.

questions.prompt: Classify the singularity of f(z) = sin(z)/z at z = 0.
questions.explanation: sin(z)/z = 1 - z²/6 + ... has no negative powers. lim_{z→0} sin(z)/z = 1, so removable.

questions.prompt: What is the formula for f^(n)(a) using Cauchy's integral formula?
questions.explanation: Cauchy's generalized formula: f^(n)(a) = (n!/2πi)∫_γ f(z)/(z-a)^(n+1) dz

questions.prompt: If f is entire (analytic everywhere in ℂ), then f has a Taylor series that converges for all z ∈ ℂ.
questions.explanation: An entire function's Taylor series has infinite radius of convergence.

questions.prompt: Which function is NOT entire?
questions.explanation: 1/z has a pole at z = 0, so it is not analytic at the origin and hence not entire.

questions.prompt: What is ∫_γ z dz where γ is any closed contour?
questions.explanation: z is entire with antiderivative z²/2. For any closed contour, ∫_γ z dz = 0 by Cauchy-Goursat.

questions.prompt: Using De Moivre's theorem, what is (1 + i)^8?
The mean value property states that for analytic f, f(a) equals:
options: The maximum of f on any circle around a
The average of f on any circle around a
The minimum of f on any circle around a
questions.explanation: Mean value property: f(a) = (1/2π)∫₀^{2π} f(a + re^{iθ}) dθ for any r where f is analytic.

title: MATH401 Final Examination
instructions: This exam is comprehensive, covering all 7 topics.
Show all work for full credit.
You may use one formula sheet.

questions.prompt: Find the residue of f(z) = z/(z²+1)² at z = i.
questions.explanation: Pole of order 2. Using the formula for order-2 poles: Res(f, i) = -i/4.

questions.prompt: Evaluate ∫_{-∞}^∞ dx/(x⁴+1) using the residue theorem.
questions.explanation: Poles in upper half-plane at e^(iπ/4) and e^(i3π/4). Computing residues gives π/√2.

questions.prompt: Use residues to evaluate ∫_0^{2π} dθ/(5 + 3cos(θ)).
questions.explanation: Substitute z = e^(iθ), cos(θ) = (z + 1/z)/2. Find poles inside |z|=1, compute residues.

questions.prompt: State Jordan's Lemma.
options: Semicircular arc integral vanishes for f→0
questions.explanation: Jordan's Lemma: If f→0 uniformly on semicircle C_R and a>0, then ∫_{C_R} f(z)e^(iaz)dz → 0 as R→∞.

questions.prompt: Compute ∫_{-∞}^∞ (cos(x))/(x²+1) dx using residues.
questions.explanation: Consider ∫ e^(ix)/(x²+1) dx. Pole at z=i. Res = e^(-1)/(2i). Real part gives π/e.

questions.prompt: Show that f(z) = z² is conformal except at z = 0. At critical points, angles are:
questions.explanation: f'(z) = 2z = 0 at z=0. At critical point, angles are multiplied by 2.

questions.prompt: The map w = e^z sends horizontal lines to:
questions.explanation: Horizontal line y=c maps to: |w| = e^x varies, arg(w) = c constant, giving a ray.

questions.prompt: State the Riemann Mapping Theorem.
options: Simply connected domain (≠ℂ) maps conformally to unit disk
Every function has a conformal extension
Möbius maps are the only conformal maps
questions.explanation: Any simply connected proper subdomain of ℂ is conformally equivalent to the unit disk.

questions.prompt: Which kernel solves the Dirichlet problem in the half-plane?
questions.explanation: The Poisson kernel for the half-plane solves Laplace's equation with given boundary values.

questions.prompt: Classify the singularity of f(z) = (e^z - 1)/z³ at z = 0.
questions.explanation: e^z - 1 = z + z²/2 + ... So f(z) = 1/z² + 1/(2z) + ... Pole of order 2.

questions.prompt: Find the Laurent series of f(z) = e^(1/z) about z = 0.
questions.explanation: e^(1/z) = 1 + 1/z + 1/(2!z²) + ... (infinitely many negative powers, essential singularity)

questions.prompt: Which is NOT a property of Möbius transformations?
questions.explanation: Möbius transformations preserve angles and map circles to circles, but do NOT preserve distances.

questions.prompt: To evaluate ∫_0^∞ (sin(x))/x dx using residues, integrate which function?
questions.explanation: Consider ∫ e^(iz)/z dz. By Jordan's lemma and semicircular contour with indent at origin.

questions.prompt: Find the residue of f(z) = 1/(z²-1) at z = 1.
questions.explanation: f(z) = 1/[(z-1)(z+1)]. Simple pole at z=1. Res = lim_{z→1} (z-1)f(z) = 1/2.

questions.prompt: What is the order of the pole of f(z) = 1/(z³sin(z)) at z = 0?
questions.explanation: sin(z) has a simple zero at 0, so 1/sin(z) has order-1 pole. Combined with 1/z³, total order is 4.

questions.prompt: Use Rouché's theorem: How many roots does z^5 + 3z + 1 have in |z| < 2?
questions.explanation: Let f(z) = z^5, g(z) = 3z+1. On |z|=2: |f| = 32, |g| ≤ 7 < 32. Same roots as z^5, which has 5.

questions.prompt: The argument principle relates ∫_γ f'/f dz to:
questions.explanation: Argument principle: (1/2πi)∫_γ f'/f dz = N - P, where N = zeros, P = poles inside γ.

questions.prompt: Every Möbius transformation can be written as a composition of translations, rotations, dilations, and inversions.
questions.explanation: Any Möbius transformation (az+b)/(cz+d) decomposes into elementary transformations.

questions.prompt: Find the image of the upper half-plane under w = (z-i)/(z+i).
questions.explanation: This Möbius transformation maps the upper half-plane to the unit disk, with i → 0.

questions.prompt: The Schwarz-Christoffel formula is used to map:
questions.explanation: Schwarz-Christoffel provides explicit conformal maps from upper half-plane to polygonal domains.

questions.prompt: Find the radius of convergence of Σ z^n/n² around z = 0.
questions.explanation: Using root test: |a_n|^(1/n) = 1/n^(2/n) → 1 as n → ∞. So R = 1.

questions.prompt: If f is analytic at z₀ with f(z₀) = 0 and f'(z₀) ≠ 0, then z₀ is:
questions.explanation: f(z₀) = 0 means z₀ is a zero. f'(z₀) ≠ 0 means the zero has order exactly 1 (simple).

questions.prompt: What is the cross-ratio (z₁, z₂; z₃, z₄)?
questions.explanation: The cross-ratio is preserved by Möbius transformations and defined by this formula.

questions.prompt: Two annuli with different moduli (ratio of radii) cannot be conformally equivalent.
questions.explanation: The modulus of an annulus is a conformal invariant. Different moduli ⟹ not conformally equivalent.
∫ z dz = 0 (entire). ∫ dz/z = 2πi. Total = 2πi.

questions.prompt: What type of singularity does f(z) = e^(1/z) have at z = 0?
questions.explanation: The Laurent series has infinitely many negative powers, indicating an essential singularity.

questions.prompt: The Joukowski transformation w = z + 1/z maps the unit circle to:
questions.explanation: For |z| = 1: w = e^(iθ) + e^(-iθ) = 2cos(θ), tracing [-2, 2] twice.

questions.prompt: If f is conformal at z₀, which condition must hold?
questions.explanation: Conformality requires f to be analytic with non-zero derivative.
Only z=1 is inside |z|=2. Res = 1/(1-3) = -1/2. Integral = 2πi(-1/2) = -πi.

questions.prompt: What is the residue of f(z) = cot(z) at z = 0?
questions.explanation: cot(z) = cos(z)/sin(z). Simple pole at 0. Res = cos(0)/[d/dz sin(z)]_{z=0} = 1/1 = 1.

questions.prompt: Find the Laurent series of 1/(z(z-1)) for 0 < |z| < 1.
questions.explanation: Partial fractions: -1/z + 1/(z-1) = -1/z - 1/(1-z) = -1/z - (1 + z + z² + ...)

questions.prompt: The identity theorem states that if two analytic functions agree on a set with a limit point in their domain, they are identical.
questions.explanation: The identity theorem is fundamental: agreement on a convergent sequence implies agreement everywhere in the connected domain.

questions.prompt: All conformal automorphisms of the unit disk have the form:
questions.explanation: Automorphisms of the unit disk are Blaschke factors composed with rotations.

questions.prompt: The exponential map w = e^z maps vertical lines to:
questions.explanation: Vertical line x = c: w = e^c e^(iy) traces a circle of radius e^c.

questions.prompt: Evaluate ∫_0^∞ dx/(1+x²)² using residues.
questions.explanation: Double pole at z=i. Res = d/dz[1/(z+i)²] at z=i = -1/(4i). Integral = πi·(-1/(4i)) = π/4.

questions.prompt: What does Morera's theorem state?
options: If f is continuous and ∫_γ f = 0 for all closed γ, then f is analytic
questions.explanation: Morera's theorem is the converse of Cauchy-Goursat.

questions.prompt: Find the image of the first quadrant under w = z².
questions.explanation: z² doubles angles. First quadrant (0 to π/2) maps to upper half-plane (0 to π).

questions.prompt: If f has a pole of order n at z₀, what is the order of the pole of f² at z₀?
questions.explanation: If f ~ 1/(z-z₀)^n near z₀, then f² ~ 1/(z-z₀)^(2n).

questions.prompt: The sum of all residues of a rational function (including at infinity) is zero.
questions.explanation: This follows from the residue theorem applied to a large contour containing all finite poles.

questions.prompt: What is the Casorati-Weierstrass theorem about essential singularities?
options: f is bounded near essential singularity
f takes every value infinitely often
The image of any punctured neighborhood is dense in ℂ
questions.explanation: Near an essential singularity, f comes arbitrarily close to every complex value.

questions.prompt: Find the principal part of the Laurent series of f(z) = 1/(z²(z-1)) at z = 0.
What is the winding number of the circle |z| = 2 (counterclockwise) about z = 1?
questions.explanation: z = 1 is inside |z| = 2. The winding number is 1 for counterclockwise traversal.
